results.title: North
results.creator_credit: Christos Tsiolkas, Spiro Economopolous and Christos Linou
results.brief_description: Collingwood - ‘Hit the North. The north is where they put most of the wogs.’ Utilising excerpts from Christos Tsiolkas’ novel ‘Loaded’, ‘North’ is a lyrical and haunting work about space and place in Melbourne’s inner-city northern suburbs. This short work reveals a history of migrant alienation and regret submerged underneath the asphalt, mortar and concrete of the modern Australian city.

results.title: reLOCATED - Mr and Mrs Kemp
results.brief_description: Kensington - this short film is created from a series of photographs and interviews with Mr and Mrs Kemp, residents of the Kensington Public Housing estate for 38 years. ‘reLOCATED’ documents the lives of residents from the estate who were moved when the estate was redeveloped. It is a visual record of how places contain the memories of people’s lives as well as a fantastic example of how you can use non-video media to make a powerful moving image story.

results.title: Stack
results.brief_description: In ‘Stack’, sound artist Ros Bandt captures sounds from the city stack emissions, a 55 metre chimney stack that extracts fumes from the Citylink tunnel. Sounds from the cylinder, the external grid and internal resonant surfaces, along with ambient sounds of the industrial extractor fans and builders working were recorded. Sections of the steel frame were electrified in order to generate original percussion timbres. The tunnel footage was shot and edited by Martin Wright.

results.title: Welcome to my home
results.brief_description: Traces the history of the Aboriginal people of Weipa South since the time white men first arrived in 1606. The early influence of church and government is shown using historic footage and interviews with Aboriginal community leaders. Examines Aboriginal life there today and the interaction with the European settlement, which was established at Weipa to mine the bauxite deposit.

results.title: The Brotherhood of St Laurence
results.creator_credit: Brotherhood of St Lawrence Production Co
results.brief_description: The Brotherhood, which is based in Melbourne, works for a better deal for disadvantaged people. This documentary describes the Brotherhood’s beginnings; its current welfare services, including accommodation for older people, a material aid service, and a sheltered workshop; its support for other independent groups; and its involvement in social issues.

results.title: Angkor, the lost city
results.brief_description: Angkor - a whole metropolis of palaces and temples recovered from the jungle which hid them for centuries until discovered in 1860 by a French naturalist. Monuments, picture tapestries in stone and Angkor Vat, a mile square temple of grey sandstone which no other church has rivalled in size, reveal the glories of the past empire of the Khmers, ancestors of the Cambodians.

results.title: Don't Think I Don't Think
results.brief_description: Documents an important conference on rights for the disabled held at Melbourne University in 1981. The disabled groups present drew up a charter of rights- rights to work, to live in their own houses etc. free of the constraints that paternalistic institutions impose

results.title: Don't think I don't think. Fair enough
results.creator_credit: Hodja Ed Res Co-op, Preston Institute of Technology, La Trobe University, Open Channel Productions and Dale Baker
results.brief_description: 1. “Don’t think I don’t think”. A workshop of the 1981 South Pacific Regional Conference on Mental Retardation. 2. “Fair enough”. The experiences of students finding difficulty in mantaining dignity and rights in the face of “hidden curricula” of school.

results.title: Wildness
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Big and Little Films, Michael McMahon and Scott Millwood
results.brief_description: Tasmanian landscape photographers Olegas Truchanas and Peter Dombrovskis had much in common. Born 22 years apart both came from Baltic Europe and migrated to Tasmania, where they developed a passion for visiting and photographing the island’s remote, wild places. Both men died before their time in the wilderness doing what they loved, and left a legacy of stunning landscape and nature photography which became synonymous with campaigns to protect Tasmania’s natural heritage. They believed that if people could see the beauty of Australia’s wild places then they might be moved to save them. Through the sixties and seventies Truchanas raised public awareness about the beauty and uniqueness of the Tasmanian wilderness, and the threat to it posed by the Tasmanian government’s massive hydro-electric schemes, through his now legendary slide presentations. After his death his work was carried on by Dombrovskis who published his images in calendars and allowed them to be used freely in the successful campaign to save the Franklin River from hydro-electric development. Combining interviews and archival footage with over 300 photographs by Truchanas and Dombrowskis, ‘Wildness’ is an accomplished tribute to the two men’s invaluable contribution to both visual culture and environmental awareness in Australia. Narrated by Nina Landis. Teachers notes are available from the Film Australia website. [www.filmaust.com.au]

results.title: Half a Chance
results.creator_credit: Seven Dimensions, Film Victoria, Eve Ash and Ted Robinson
results.brief_description: A collection of dramatised case studies of young offenders on probation. Both the probationer and the probation officer talk about the problems and advantages of this type of supervision.
